item.title: Trump Urges Iran to Make a Deal ‘Before It’s Too Late’
item.description: US President Donald Trump said Friday in a post on Truth Social that he had given Iran “chance after chance to make a deal,” urging it to make one now “before it is too late.” Trump’s comments came after Israel carried out airstrikes against Iran’s nuclear facilities. Tyler Kendall reports on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: European Gas Prices Jump as Middle East Risk Returns to Market
item.description: European natural gas prices surged after Israel carried out a wave of strikes against Iran, raising fears of a wider war in a region that’s key to global energy supplies.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha

media:content.media:description: A natural gas supply at a district heating plant in Stuttgart, Germany.

item.title: Israel Orders Temporary Shutdown of Its Biggest Gas Field
item.description: Israel ordered its biggest natural gas field to be temporarily shut down, the country’s energy ministry said.
item.dc:creator: Alisa Odenheimer, Anna Shiryaevskaya

media:content.media:description: A view of the platform of the Leviathan natural gas field in the Mediterranean Sea ifrom the Israeli northern coastal beach of Nasholim, on August 29, 2022.

item.title: Oil Spikes as Israeli Attacks on Iran Stoke Fears of Wider War
item.description: Oil surged as much as 13% after Israel carried out waves of strikes against Iran, raising fears of a wider war in a region that accounts for a third of global crude production.
item.dc:creator: Rob Verdonck, Jack Wittels

item.title: Stocks Fall, Oil and Gold Jump as Israel Hits Iran: Markets Wrap
item.description: Oil jumped and stocks slid after Israel attacked Iran’s nuclear program sites in a major escalation of tensions in the Middle East. Gold advanced.
item.dc:creator: Julien Ponthus, Anand Krishnamoorthy

item.title: Deadly Air India Crash Puts Ambitious Turnaround Plans at Risk
item.description: Air India Ltd.’s ambitious plans to transform itself from a stale, financially troubled carrier into a profitable world-class airline face their biggest test yet after the deadliest aviation accident in more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: Satviki Sanjay, Mihir Mishra

media:content.media:description: Aircraft debris at the crash site of Air India Ltd. flight AI171 in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, on June 12. Photographer: Siddharaj Solanki/Bloomberg

item.title: Israel's Strikes on Iran Raises Risk of Wider War | Bloomberg The Pulse 06/13
item.description: Brent surged almost 10% after Israel carried out military strikes against Iran. Israel targeted nuclear facilities and killed senior military commanders in a major escalation that could spark a broad war in the Middle East. Explosions were heard across Tehran, Natanz — home to a key atomic site — and other cities, according to local and social media. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel — which used 200 air force planes and said it hit around 100 targets — had “struck at the heart of Iran’s nuclear enrichment program.” Today's guests: Hugh Gimber, JPMorgan Asset Management Global Market Strategist, Julien Barnes-Dacey, European Council on Foreign Relations Middle East and North Africa Programme Director, Phoenix Kalen, SGCIB, Emerging Markets Research Head, Lynette Nusbacher, Nusbacher & Associates Chair. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Inter Milan to Repay Bonds Tied to Sponsorship and Media Rights
item.description: FC Internazionale Milano SpA is set to give an early payback to holders of its high yield bonds backed by the football club’s sponsorship and media rights.
item.dc:creator: Giulia Morpurgo

media:content.media:description: Inter Milan's Italian midfielder celebrates scoring his team's fourth goal during the UEFA Champions League semi-final second leg football match.

item.title: Senegal Must Clarify $7 Billion Fiscal Gap Before IMF Talks
item.description: Senegal’s dollar bonds plunged after the International Monetary Fund said it wants more clarity on a $7 billion fiscal hole discovered under the previous administration before it can discuss a fresh program with the new government.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije

media:content.media:description: Vehicles pass an Ola Energy Holdings Ltd. gas station in Dakar, Senegal, on Sunday, Nov. 26, 2023. West Africa’s growth slowed to 3.7% this year from 3.9% in 2022 due to the global economy and higher inflation, the Economic Community of West African States said. Photographer: Damian Lemański/Bloomberg

item.title: China, Turkey Renew Currency Swap Deal Worth Almost $5 Billion
item.description: Turkey and China have renewed a currency swap agreement, allowing their central banks to exchange as much as 189 billion liras ($4.8 billion) or 35 billion yuan over the next three years.
item.dc:creator: Ugur Yilmaz

media:content.media:description: ISTANBUL, TURKEY - JULY 29: Detail as a man counts Turkish Lira at a currency exchange office on July 29, 2020 in Istanbul, Turkey. The Turkish Lira remains under pressure after briefly trading at a record low against the euro of 8.17 on Tuesday amid investor concerns around Turkey's foreign denomination debt and potential EU sanctions. (Photo by Chris McGrath/Getty Images) Photographer: Chris McGrath/Getty Images

item.title: Pre-IPO Marketplace Hiive Seeks New Cash as Competition Heats Up
item.description: Hiive Markets Ltd., an online trading platform for shares of venture-backed companies, is hoping to raise as much as $100 million as soon as this year, its chief executive officer said.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Seal

media:content.media:description: The skyline of Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, on Wednesday, Sept. 25, 2024. Vancouver is at the forefront of “harm reduction” policies, those aimed at reducing drugs’ dangers without moral judgments or demands that users quit.

item.title: PSP Hunts for More Canada Deals as Assets Surge to $220 Billion
item.description: Canada’s Public Sector Pension Investment Board is looking to deploy more capital in its home country after years of global expansion that has pushed its investment portfolio to C$300 billion ($220 billion).
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion, Layan Odeh

media:content.media:description: Deborah Orida, president and chief executive officer of PSP Investments, during an event at The Canadian Club in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on Monday, May 6, 2024. The Public Sector Pension Investment Board (PSP Investments) is one of Canada's largest pension investors.

item.title: Middle East Nations Close Airspace After Israel Strikes Iran
item.description: Airlines traversing the Mideast face new challenges after Israel launched air strikes against Iran, leading a number of countries in the region to close their airspace.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan

media:content.media:description: BEIRUT, LEBANON - JUNE 13: Most flights scheduled to depart from Beirut-Rafic Hariri International Airport are cancelled following Israel's attacks on Iran, on June 13, 2025, in Beirut,

item.title: Dollar’s Haven Status Faces a Key Test After Israel Strikes
item.description: The dollar’s reputation as a crisis haven is being put to the test after the US currency staged only a limited rally in response to an Israeli attack on Iran that stoked fears of a wider conflict in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Carson, Winnie Hsu, Naomi Tajitsu

media:content.media:description: Stacks of U.S. $100 bills are arranged for a photograph in New York, U.S., on Thursday, Feb. 7, 2013. The U.S. dollar advanced in trading today to the highest in almost three weeks against a basket of major currencies.

item.title: Martin Wiggen: Risk of Israel-Iran Conflict Escalating, Oil Price Spiking
item.description: Israel's strike on Iran is at risk of escalating the Middle Eastern conflict, with potential further consequences for the price of crude oil Nadia Martin Wiggen of Svelland Capital. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Beijing’s Borrowing Drove Credit Growth Despite Weak Loan Demand
item.description: A big jump in Chinese government bond sales drove credit growth in May, compensating for weak borrowing by households.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Buildings in Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China, on Monday, March 3, 2025. President Xi Jinping heads into China's biggest political huddle of the year with his economy finally getting back some swagger. Photographer: Raul Ariano/Bloomberg

item.title: Options Signal Emerging-Market Stock Outperformance Could Fade
item.description: For US traders, developing-country stocks have been a surprising source of returns as Donald Trump’s trade war roiled the S&P 500 Index. But if options are any guide, that outperformance may soon be a thing of the past.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Goyder

item.title: Bohl: Already Seeing Israel-Iran Worst-Case Scenario
item.description: "It can't get worse than the situation we're in right now" says Ryan Bohl, Senior MENA Analyst at RANE. Bohl adds that the next thing to watch is whether Iran will widen widens its targets to include countries like the US and Saudi Arabia as the conflict escalates. He speaks to Jennifer Zabasajja on Horizons Middle East & Africa. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Gold Jumps After Israel Launches Strikes on Iran’s Nuclear Sites
item.description: Gold spiked after Israel conducted airstrikes targeting Iran’s nuclear sites and military leadership, raising fears that hostilities between the two nations may spiral into a wider regional conflict.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross, Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: One kilogram gold bars at the ABC Refinery smelter, operated by Pallion, in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, April 17, 2025. Gold paused its record-breaking rally amid optimism over US-Japan trade talks, after bullion earlier reached another all-time high. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

item.title: Balderton Capital's Liautaud on Europe Investment, AI
item.description: Balderton Capital Managing Partner Bernard Liautaud speaks to Bloomberg's Tom Mackenzie on the sidelines of the Founders Forum in Oxfordshire. He says that Europe’s goal isn’t to out scale other regions in AI, but the aim is to build an ecosystem to achieve compute, data, talent, and regulatory support. This interview occurred on Thursday June 12. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Duo of Nordic IPOs Surge Above Offer Prices in Early Trading
item.description: Two initial public offerings in the Nordics traded substantially above their offer prices on Friday, cementing a trend of strong debuts in the region.
item.dc:creator: Charles Capel

media:content.media:description: A trading bell inside the Nasdaq Swedish Stock Exchange. Photographer: Mikael Sjoberg/Bloomberg

item.title: US Equity Funds Hit by Biggest Outflows in 11 Weeks, BofA Says
item.description: US stock funds suffered the biggest outflows in almost three months, according to data published by Bank of America Corp., adding to signs that the equity market rally is stalling.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani

item.title: BNP Paribas: EUR/USD Can Keep Heading Higher
item.description: Alexander Jekov from BNP Paribas Markets 360 says there is "a structural rotation out of the dollar currently underway by global investors." Speaking on Bloomberg Television, Jekov adds: "We'd be inclined to say EUR/USD over the medium term can continue to head higher." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Novo Nordisk Overtakes SAP as Europe’s Most Valuable Company
item.description: Novo Nordisk A/S reclaimed its position as Europe’s most valuable public company, overtaking software developer SAP SE.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Pham

media:content.media:description: Novo Nordisk Wegovy injection pen production.

item.title: Trump Economic Advisor, Stephen Miran, on Tariffs and Tax Cuts
item.description: How is all this supposed to work?
item.dc:creator: Carmen Rodriguez, Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers Stephen Miran

item.title: Trump Economic Advisor, Stephen Miran, on Tariffs and Tax Cuts
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

item.title: Trump Economic Advisor Miran Downplays Fears of Investment Fallout from ‘Revenge Tax’
item.description: The White House’s chief economist dismissed concerns that a controversial provision in President Donald Trump’s tax-and-spending bill would drive away foreign bond investors, calling such fears a “misinterpretation.”
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie, Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Stephen Miran Photographer: Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: WiseTech Banks Market APAC’s Largest M&A Loan of The Year
item.description: Lenders to Australian software developer WiseTech Global Ltd. are syndicating a $3 billion loan backing its acquisition of US-based supply chain software platform E2open Parent Holdings Inc, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Chien Mi Wong, Sharon Klyne

item.title: Oil-Tanker Operator Is ‘Far More Hesitant’ About Cargoes in Middle East
item.description: Frontline Ltd., one of the world’s largest oil-tanker operators, is “far more hesitant” about offering its vessels to haul cargoes from the Persian Gulf following overnight airstrikes on Iran by Israel.
item.dc:creator: Alaric Nightingale

media:content.media:description: A tanker leaves the Basra Oil Terminal in The Gulf fifty kilometers south of Iraq, Sunday, December 7, 2003. Oil-tanker rates for shipping crude from the Middle East may rise next quarter as OPEC boosts output to temper near-record prices, increasing demand for vessels owned by companies such as Teekay Shipping Corp. and Frontline Ltd. Photographer: SHAWN BALDWIN

item.title: Dundee Precious to Buy Adriatic Metals for $1.25 Billion
item.description: Dundee Precious Metals Inc. agreed to buy Adriatic Metals Plc, which operates a silver project in Bosnia and Herzegovina, for about $1.25 billion, as miners respond to surging precious metal prices.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Biesheuvel, Dylan Griffiths

media:content.media:description: Adriatic Metals Source: Adriatic Metals Plc
